lines.text: Nobody wants to see me down like I wants to see me up.
Sure I may be tuckered, and I may give out, but I won't give IN!

[in France]
Here I'm pleasant, at home I'm vulgar, I guess it's like here you eat snails, at home you step on them.
It's not the money I love, it's the not having it I hate.
Molly sure know what she was doin' when she made this place red. The blood don't show.
At last, this place looks lived in!
[Molly is reading the newspaper reports of the free-for-all that took place at her social party]
But it's lies, all lies! Everybody knows the Merry Christmas Saloon ain't no fancy house! And the things he quotes me saying! All those blanks that stand for bad words!
[Thinks]
Well... guess I did let a couple go.
[Reads from paper]

"'One thing's for blank sure,' said Mrs. Brown. 'This time we ain't puttin' up with no blank blank Rocky Mountain rudeness!'" Ohhh! And the worst of all! It isn't even on the Society page! It's on the *Sports* page!

[reading the ring]
"Always remember two things I love you and the name of the bank."
I mean more to me than I mean to anybody else.
I'm interested in everything because I don't know nothing.

[to Johnny Brown]
Where I come from we drown runts of the litter like you.

[reading]
The rat sees the cat, the cat sees the rat, I have a new hat, it is a red hat. What happened to the rat?
The cat ate it.

[describing the only boy interested in Molly]
He tried to show her his pa's hayloft, she tied a tin can to his tail and sent him rattling down the road.
Serve the Lord and a hot breakfast, then you can look for your Irish Catholic man with the roof that don't leak.
He's going to have to be more than an Irish Catholic.
What more is there?
Well if he's going to crawl in next to me, he's going to have to be the richest Irish Catholic next to the Pope.

[singing]
And if that house is red and has a big brass bed, I'm LIIIIIIIVING THERE!
What's that mean? Best regards?
Well it means not just 'regards', but best regards.
